#Text=2 .
#Text=Interferometric Model and Performance of Gaofen-3
#Text=The ScanSAR mode is a SAR mode with a width swath .
#Text=By beam scanning , ScanSAR can observe several sub-swathes simultaneously .
#Text=These sub-swathes are located at different points along the range direction .
#Text=Together , they can cover a whole wide swath .
#Text=Because only a single beam is used in ScanSAR , the observing time must be separated and allocated to different sub-swathes .
#Text=Thus , for a single sub-swath , the observing signals are in the burst mode .
#Text=During bursts , signal pulses are transmitted to the sub-swath , but no signal pulses are used between bursts .
#Text=In burst mode , the azimuth resolution is decreased .
#Text=ScanSAR can cover a width swath but with low resolution .
#Text=Thus , ScanSAR is suitable for rapid mapping , but not suitable for subtle measurement .
#Text=ScanSAR interferometry is based on the ScanSAR mode , so it has similar characteristics .
#Text=The ScanSAR interferometry of Gaofen-3 works in a repeat-pass mode .
#Text=The two images achieved from the two passes may be unsynchronized .
#Text=In this paper , we used a pair of Gaofen-3 interferometric images over Kunlun Mountain .
#Text=These images were achieved in ScanSAR mode for wide-swath remote sensing .
#Text=The main parameters are listed as Table 1 .
#Text=In the parameters , the PRFs and velocities are different .
#Text=Burst durations are decided by PRFs and pulse numbers , so they were also different .
#Text=Because there was no burst synchronization between the two images , a burst central time difference also existed .
#Text=These unsynchronized characteristics influence interferometric performance .
#Text=From the ScanSAR principle , the ScanSAR mode observes the Earth ’s surface only in bursts .
#Text=It is different from the normal stripmap mode , which uses continuous observation .
#Text=Thus , the interferometric performance of the ScanSAR mode needs to consider these burst characteristics in the signal model .
#Text=The burst characteristics also include the above-mentioned unsynchronizations .

#Text=This paper analyzed the interferometric performance of the ScanSAR signal model : ( 1 ) where ( 2 ) where is the slow time , is the fast time , is the scattering coefficient , stands for azimuth envelope , stands for pulse envelope , stands for rectangular function , is the vertical distance from the orbit to target , is the moment when the vertical sight line passing target , is the time offset caused by squint , is the equivalent velocity , is the burst central time , is the burst cycle time , is the burst duration , and k is the pulse modulation rate .
#Text=The ScanSAR signal can be processed by the extended chirp scaling ( ECS ) algorithm .
#Text=In this algorithm , the signal is first translated into the range-Doppler domain and processed along the range dimension , and then processed by azimuth scaling and focusing .
#Text=The range processing includes chirp scaling , bulk range cell migration correction ( RCMC ) , range compressing , and second-range compressing .
#Text=After range processing , we retrieve the processed signal in the range-Doppler domain .

#Text=Considering a single burst , the processed signal can be expressed as follows : ( 3 ) where ( 4 ) ( 5 ) ( 6 ) is the azimuth frequency , is a constant coefficient , is the pulse duration of the transmitted signal , and is the central frequency of the chirp signal .
#Text=By azimuth scaling processing , the second phase term of the range processed signal can be transformed as follows : ( 7 ) where is the referenced range distance .
#Text=In order to focus the signal along the azimuth dimension , the signal can be processed by the spectral analysis ( SPECAN ) algorithm .
#Text=According to the algorithm , the signal needs to be transformed into the time domain .
#Text=In this domain , the signal can be dechirped by multiplying .
#Text=The dechirped signal is expressed as : ( 8 ) where ( 9 )
#Text=The signal can then be transformed by Fourier-transform ( FT ) along the azimuth dimension .
#Text=The transformed signal is : ( 10 )
#Text=By multiplying , the azimuth phase of the signal can be compensated .
#Text=This is the last step of the SPECAN algorithm .
#Text=At this stage , we can acquire the focused image , the expression of which can be approximated by the following equation : ( 11 )

#Text=In ScanSAR interferometry , the interferometric image pair can also be expressed as Equation ( 11 ) with slow time , fast time , target time , target range , burst central time , Doppler modulation rate , burst duration and equivalent velocity instead of , , , , , , , and , where the subscript “ ” means the image index . “ i = 1 ” indicates the master image and “ i = 2 ” means the slave image .
#Text=After image co-registration , the slave image can be expressed as : ( 12 )
#Text=Then we substitute Equations ( 11 ) and ( 12 ) into the expression of interferometric coherence : ( 13 )

#Text=We can get : ( 14 ) ( 15 ) ( 16 ) where is the coherence caused by the baseline and is the coherence caused by burst central time difference . is the same as the corresponding coherence in stripmap mode , and can be simplified as follows : ( 17 ) where and .
#Text=From Equation ( 17 ) , we can see that the interferometric coherence is influenced by the burst central time difference .
#Text=The difference needs to be kept low relative to the burst duration .
#Text=The interferometric coherence is also influenced by the burst duration difference as a secondary factor .
#Text=The velocity difference and PRF difference relate to the burst central time difference and burst duration difference .
